Cedric Beust wrote:
>  > From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> 
>  > These examples seem to fall into one category: an object
>  > representing a resource we have released.
> 
> Not necessarily.
> 
> Take one of your classes with more than ten methods.
> 
> Can you really say that all the public methods of this class can be invoked
> at all time without any pre-requisite?
> 
> I would be very surprised if the answer was yes (it would mean your
> application is basically based on a bunch of static methods acting on
> stateless objects).

I don't have too many examples of classes with more than ten methods, so 
it might be difficult to say. (I'm not being facetious; it's true.)

I also doubt your implication in the last paragraph. A trivial example 
would be a class with mostly query methods. I don't have a good 
nontrivial example at that moment.

Also keep in mind the difference between an insane object, for which a 
given operation might be undefined or worthy of rejecting, and a sane 
object in a certain state in which a given operation might do nothing 
interesting.
--
